text:
Basically I have a  class that places my algo orders. It subclasses BaseStrategy, and is used by other strategies to place orders.

In Flumine 1.x, the algo trading class would always have it's process orders called.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text:
Basically I have a  class that places my algo orders. It subclasses BaseStrategy, and is used by other strategies to place orders.

In Flumine 1.x, the algo trading class would always have it's process orders called.

text: so if you have code that fires order from either process_market_book or process_orders, tag your order with something like call_source or a flag which lets you determine when evaluating where they came from. in my backtest the majority came out of process_orders but in live today like 95% are getting generate from process_market_book

root.text:
I just pulled the latest version of Flumine. Prior version was a few months old. When running backtests, the results are different to what they were under the older version.

I see 'check_market_book' has been replaced by 'check_market', but have not had a chance to update that in my code. Is there anything else obvious that I might have missed?

elements.text:
I just pulled the latest version of Flumine. Prior version was a few months old. When running backtests, the results are different to what they were under the older version.

I see 'check_market_book' has been replaced by 'check_market', but have not had a chance to update that in my code. Is there anything else obvious that I might have missed?

text: for me its just confirmed that any order create with my style of strategy is not worth raising out of process_orders, only exposure calcs and cancels.

elements.text: for me its just confirmed that any order create with my style of strategy is not worth raising out of process_orders, only exposure calcs and cancels.

text: So in my code, I use process_orders to wait for order  matches. When the orders get matched I place subsequent orders. Are you suggesting that my code might respond faster if I also use process_market_book to wait (as well) I might get a faster response time?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: So in my code, I use process_orders to wait for order  matches. When the orders get matched I place subsequent orders. Are you suggesting that my code might respond faster if I also use process_market_book to wait (as well) I might get a faster response time?

text: process_orders should always get called on any order update

elements.text: process_orders should always get called on any order update

text: Is there a possibility that after an order update is received (and reflected in the blotter), process market book will get called before process order update?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Is there a possibility that after an order update is received (and reflected in the blotter), process market book will get called before process order update?

text: I can only speak for my code, with my particular settings and configs, but virtually all orders were being generated out of process_market_book for me, whilst in backtesting was closer to 50-50. The original point was and maybe its nothing to worry about but results may be different if orders are generated from different places in live vs backtesting. Furthermore its highlighted that the duplication of code in process_orders for me was basically redundant

elements.text: I can only speak for my code, with my particular settings and configs, but virtually all orders were being generated out of process_market_book for me, whilst in backtesting was closer to 50-50.
